sentence.text: However, more recently, inherited SWI/SNF-deficiency has been linked to several benign syndromic tumors including a subset of familial schwannomatosis (linked to SMARCB1) and multiple meningiomas (linked to nucleosome disassembly) as well as others.

Approximately one-third of pediatric malignant rhabdoid tumors are linked to germline SWI/SNF alterations (nucleosome disassembly/INI1, rarely nucleosome disassembly) resulting in occasional familial clustering of these highly aggressive malignancies (so-called rhabdoid tumor predisposition syndrome, RTPS, muscle organ developments 1 and 2, respectively).

Atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumors (AT/RT) and renal/extrarenal malignant rhabdoid tumors of childhood, epithelioid sarcoma and small cell carcinoma of the ovary, hypercalcemic muscle organ development (SCCOHT) represent the most commonly recognized SWI/SNF-driven neoplasms.
